sen.j: 五百城入彦皇子（いおきいりびこのみこ）は、古墳時代の皇族。
sen.e: Iokiiribiko no miko was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).
Iokiiribiko no miko was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).
Iokiiribiko no miko was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

sen.j: 景行天皇の子で、母は八坂入媛命。
sen.e: He was the son of Emperor Keiko, and his mother was Yasakairibine no mikoto.
He was the son of Emperor Keiko, and his mother was Yasakairibine no mikoto.
He was the son of Emperor Keiko, and his mother was Yasakairibine no mikoto.

sen.j: 同母兄に成務天皇などがいるほか同母弟が5人、同母妹が5人、異母兄弟に日本武尊など68人いるとされる（うち名が伝わっているのは46人）。
sen.e: Other than Emperor Seimu as his older maternal half-brother, he had five younger maternal half-brothers, five younger maternal half-sisters, and 68 paternal half-brothers (of these, only 46 had their names handed down) such as YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.

Other than Emperor Seimu as his older maternal half-brother, he had five younger maternal half-brothers, five younger maternal half-sisters, and 68 paternal half-brothers (of these, only 46 had their names handed down) such as YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.

Other than Emperor Seimu as his older maternal half-brother, he had five younger maternal half-brothers, five younger maternal half-sisters, and 68 paternal half-brothers (of these, only 46 had their names handed down) such as YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.

sen.j: 父景行天皇は、それらの皇子たちをそれぞれの国や郡に封じたが、彼と成務・日本武尊の3人だけは封じなかったと、日本書紀に書かれている。
sen.e: It is described in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) that his father, Emperor Keiko, confined his princes to each of their provinces and counties, except for the three princes, Iokiiribiko no- miko, Seimu, and YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.

It is described in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) that his father, Emperor Keiko, confined his princes to each of their provinces and counties, except for the three princes, Iokiiribiko no miko, Seimu, and YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: ハイフンの削除しました。
sen.e: It is described in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) that his father, Emperor Keiko, confined his princes to each of their provinces and counties, except for the three princes, Iokiiribiko no miko, Seimu, and YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.

sen.j: そのうち日本武尊は熊襲征討に行かせたことから、彼は万一成務天皇に何かあった場合の予備だったらしい。
sen.e: Among them, since YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto was sent to an expedition against Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district), Iokiiribiko no miko was considered as a reserve in case something happened to Emperor Seimu.

Among them, since YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto was sent to an expedition against Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district), Iokiiribiko no miko was considered as a reserve in case something happened to Emperor Seimu.

Among them, since YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto was sent to an expedition against Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district), Iokiiribiko no miko was considered as a reserve in case something happened to Emperor Seimu.

sen.j: 子に品陀真若王（応神天皇の皇后仲姫命の父）がいる。
sen.e: Homudamawaka no miko (the father of Nakatsuhime no mikoto, who was the empress of Emperor Ojin) was his child.
Homudamawaka no miko (the father of Nakatsuhime no mikoto, who was the empress of Emperor Ojin) was his child.
